Award.AwardTitle: Heart of Glass: Volatile Release and Petrogenesis of Columbia River Flood Basalt Lavas Through Study of Melt Inclusions and Glassy Tephra
Award.AbstractNarration:
Historical experience tells us that volcanic eruptions can directly cause short-term (few years) global climate perturbations through the release of gases to the atmosphere. What is less clear is the capacity for very large eruptions to produce catastrophic and/or long-lasting climate change. Such eruptions lie outside recorded human experience but their products are evident in the geologic record. Among this class of events are the gigantic piles of frozen lava flows that make up continental flood basalt regions. Individual flood lava eruptions may be hundreds of times bigger than the largest historically-erupted lavas, with, potentially, proportionately severe effects on climate. The youngest and best-studied continental flood basalt province is the Columbia River Basalts (CRB), which formed around 16 million years ago and now cover about 200,000 square kilometers of the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. Previous studies of gas release associated with the eruption of these lavas have focused on late flows that post-date the main outpouring of basalt. This project employs a new approach that targets glassy volcanic ash found in the areas around the volcanic vents, rather than the equivalent crystallized, 'stony' lavas themselves. The glasses, and the crystals that they hold, preserve a higher fidelity record of eruption outgassing than do the lavas, allowing estimates of atmospheric pollution caused by the most intense phase of CRB activity. These estimates will constitute 'ground truth' that can help constrain, for instance, models for regional and global climate disturbance at the time of eruption.

Before now, studies of degassing from CRB have focused on the porphyritic Wanapum lavas (6% of the whole CRB), which post-date the peak activity of flood volcanism represented by the Grande Ronde lavas (70% of the whole CRB). The principle barrier to study of the Grande Ronde has been a perception that they are aphyric, i.e. they do not contain melt inclusion-bearing 'phenocrysts' (crystals that grew in the magma prior to eruption). Melt inclusions in crystals preserve the original gas content of the magma (chiefly H2O, CO2, S species) that can then be compared with fully degassed groundmass basalt to gain an estimate of gas loss. However, study of naturally water-quenched basaltic glasses from the vent areas of Grande Ronde lava flows shows that they do indeed contain melt inclusion-bearing phenocrysts, small, but nonetheless amenable to analysis by microbeam methods. Additionally, some of the glassy ash fragments have been quenched prior to degassing and can also be analyzed to gain an estimate of gas loss. The data will be used to estimate fluxes of S, H2O and CO2 to the atmosphere from CRB activity. This in turn will provide constraints on the potential of the CRB for cooling (due to S pollution of the atmosphere) vs. warming (due to CO2 release to the atmosphere) the Miocene climate, both of which hypotheses have been advanced by previous workers, but in both cases supported by little data. A further area of study is afforded by the fact that the glasses preserve a broader range of overall chemical compositions than do the equivalent lavas, potentially providing new insights into the ultimate origins of the flood basalt magmas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tbe effect of volcanic eruptions on climate, via gas emissions at the vent site, is well attested from the historical record, but the largest eruptions seen in the much longer geological record outstrip historic events by a factor of at least x100 and as much as x1,000. The Miocene Columbia River Basalt Group (CRBG), in the northwestern United States, is Earth’s youngest and best-studied flood basalt province, but attempts to link it with mid-Miocene global change have proven elusive. Part of the difficulty lies in a lack of comprehensive data for gas emissions from the most intense main phase of activity of the CRBG, which happened between approximately 16.7 and 16.0 million years ago. In  this project, we analyzed sulfur contents in magmas that erupted to form the Wapshilla Ridge Member and associated units of the Grande Ronde Basalt, the most voluminous portion of the Columbia River Basalt Group, erupted at the time of peak magma flux. The key to the project was recognizing and exploiting the occurrence of fresh volcanic glass in near-vent ash deposits associated with the flood lava eruptions of the CRBG. Fresh basaltic glass, despite being the most desirable material for analysis,  is quite rare on Earth, and is principally found where erupting magma has been quenched by water, in this case ground- or surface water around the eruptive fissures and vents that fed the lava flows. We sampled and analyzed glassy lapilli (small chips of quenched magma) as well as melt inclusions, tiny blobs of glass enclosed within crystals inside lapilli. The latter act as pressure vessels that preserve the original volatile content of the magma, whereas the former represent degassed magma. The difference in volatile content (S, Cl, CO2, H2O) represents the amount of gas lost to the atmosphere, in the case of S as SO2, which is ultimately oxidized and hydrated to H2SO4 (sulfuric acid) aerosols that linger in the atmosphere and block sunlight from reaching Earth’s surface. The magmatic S contents in the very voluminous (~40,000 km3) Wapshilla Ridge Member scale up to 242–305 Gt SO2 released to the atmosphere over a maximum time period of 94 k.y. This is an amount of SO2 equivalent to what would be produced from the 1815 C.E. eruption of Mount Tambora, Indonesia (famous for causing the 1816 “year without a summer”), repeated every day for a period of 11–16 years. The time of the Wapshilla Ridge Member eruption coincides with a global temperature drop and glacial advance that interrupted the peak of the Miocene Climatic Optimum, but refinement of basalt eruption tempo is needed before a cause-and-effect relation can be established. In contrast, the release of CO2 from the eruptions was considerably less than that emitted in the modern industrial era and was probably insufficient to perturb global climate.

At the time of eruption, Wapshilla Ridge magma was saturated in S, as indicated by the presence of an iron sulphide phase inside some melt inclusions. However, petrogenetically related, more primitive Columbia River basalt glasses, from the Imnaha Basalts and the Meyer Ridge Member of the Grande Ronde, are not S-saturated, but may represent parental compositions to the Wapshilla Ridge lavas that became saturated through fractional crystallization. We conclude that the assumption of S-saturation in basalts, assumed in published simplified models for S-release from eruptions, is not always warrannted.

The glass and analyses contain additional information about the magma reservoirs that fed the eruptions. Variations in concentrations of non-volatile elements in glasses from different vent sites of the same flow (or group of flows identified as a single mappable unit) indicate that individual basalt units were not derived from well-stirred reservoirs, and that whole-rock basalt samples, typically used for chemical correlation of individual flows over long distances, are themselves partially averaged compositions.

The CRBG erupted in a complex tectonic environment, which has allowed various models for the origins and mantle sources contributing to the flood basalt volcanism. In the course of this project, we have amassed the first large data set on Cl abundances in CRBG liquids. Chlorine is an effective tracer of the participation of subducting slab-derived fluids in the generation of basalt magmas. The data indicate a clear but highly variable role for fluids in the production of CRBG magmas.
